document.value: Support Center SaaS Center Monitoring Center Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Features OpenSearchServer is an open source search engine and crawler software based on the best open source technologies. Search functions Advanced full-text search features Phonetic search Advanced boolean search with query language Clustered results with faceting and collapsing Filter search using sub-requests (including negative filters) Geolocation Spell-checking Relevance customization using algebraic functions Search suggestion facility (auto-completion) Parsers Parsers recognize and analyze the MIME type of crawled documents or file extensions and then automatically extract information necessary for indexing (Title, Text, Author, hypertext links, etc.). Supported formats are: HTML / XHTML MS Office documents (Word, Excel, Powerpoint) OpenOffice documents Adobe PDF (with OCR) RTF, Plaintext Audio files metadata (wav, mp3, AIFF, Ogg) Torrent files OCR over images General REST API (XML and JSON) SOAP Web Service Monitoring module Index replication Scheduler for management of periodic tasks WordPress plugin and Drupal module Indexation Supports 17 languages Fields schema with analyzers in each language Several filters: n-gram, lemmatization, shingle, stripping diacritic from words,… Automatic language recognition Named entity recognition Word synonyms and expression synonyms Export indexed terms with frequencies Crawlers This is the module which creates the index that will process the queries and return answers. OpenSearchServer is equipped with several crawlers that each allow you to browse and index different categories of content: The web crawler for internet, extranet and intranet The file systems crawler for local and remote files (NFS, SMB/CIFS, FTP, FTPS) The database crawler for all JDBC databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, SQL Server, …) Each crawler offers a list of parameters allowing developers to customize its behavior. Filter inclusion or exclusion with wildcards Session parameters removal SQL join and linked files support Screenshot capture Sitemap import Social network Tweets concernant "#opensearchserve OR opensearchserver OR "open search server" OR jaeksoft" Legal information © 2013 OpenSearchServer Responsive Theme powered by WordPress

Support Center SaaS Center Monitoring Center Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Community OpenSearchServer has been available as an independent project in Sourceforge since April 2009 and proposed under the GNU/GPL 3 license. We are very happy about the growth and strength of our developers’ community. All feedback is welcome and many people have originated product enhancements or new features delivery. This is the power of the Open Source and we are very grateful for the high level of participation. Explain your needs to us, let’s share our experiences. Download Current stable and certified release: v1.3.1 For Windows, Mac OS X: opensearchserver-1.3.1.zip For Linux, Solaris, BSD, Unix: opensearchserver-1.3.1.tar.gz Record of changes: CHANGELOG.txt All files: JAVA, PHP and ASP.NET libraries Latest beta release: v1.4-beta3 For Windows, Mac OS X: opensearchserver-1.4.zip For Linux, Solaris, BSD, Unix: opensearchserver-1.4.tar.gz Record of changes: CHANGELOG.txt All files: JAVA, PHP and ASP.NET libraries Old stable and certified release: v1.2.4 For Windows, Mac OS X: opensearchserver-1.2.4.zip For Linux, Solaris, BSD, Unix: opensearchserver-1.2.4.tar.gz Record of changes: CHANGELOG.txt All files: JAVA, PHP and ASP.NET libraries Versioning principles Stable version Stability is a subjective judgement and you should always read carrefully the change log txt for any version you intend to make use of. Stable releases may contain a small number of relatively minor bugs. Stable releases are intended for production use and are expected to run stably for extended periods of time. Beta version Releases may contain some untested functionality and / or a number of relatively minor bugs. Beta releases are not expected to run stably. Alpha version Releases may contain large amounts of untested / missing functionality required by the specification and / or significant bugs and are not expected to run stably for any length of time. Documentation The documentation includes tutorials, installation guides and manuals . The Wiki is the primary source for the documentation. It contains contributions from both the community and our development team. Forums Request help from the community, and check previous threads for relevant discussions Help OpenSearchServer grow and thrive by launching new threads Check all OpenSearchServer forums Bugs and evolutions The tracking system allows you to report issues, suggest new functionalities, and to track the answers to your requests. Report a bug Suggest a new feature Source code You can access the source code using Subversion. Please follow the instructions. IRC Channel The IRC OpenSearchServer channel is a live conversation with OpenSearchServer enthusiasts and experts to talk about the software. IRC Server: chat.freenode.net - Channel: #OpenSearchServer For information on what an IRC (Internet Relay Chat) is: http://www.irchelp.org/ You may use your own IRC client or our web page . Social network Tweets concernant "#opensearchserve OR opensearchserver OR "open search server" OR jaeksoft" Legal information © 2013 OpenSearchServer Responsive Theme powered by WordPress

Support Center Saas Center Monitoring Center Accueil Fonctionnalités Offres et tarifs Documentation Communauté Newsletter Contact A propos Presse Communauté OpenSearchServer est disponible en tant que projet indépendant sur la plateforme Sourceforge depuis avril 2009, proposé sous licence GNU/GPL. Nous avons à coeur de satisfaire les demandes et besoins, de fournir les dernières informations relatives au projet OpenSearchServer. Nous sommes très fiers de voir la communauté grandir jour après jour. Vos retours sont les bienvenus, ceux-ci sont très régulièrement à l’origine d’améliorations de notre produit ou de nouvelles fonctions. Exprimez vos besoins, partageons nos expériences. Téléchargement Version actuelle stable et certifiée: v1.3.1 Pour Windows, Mac OS X: opensearchserver-1.3.1.zip Pour Linux, Solaris, Unix: opensearchserver-1.3.1.tar.gz Suivi des modifications: CHANGELOG.txt Tous les fichiers: Librairies JAVA, PHP et ASP.NET Dernière version beta: v1.4-beta3 Pour Windows, Mac OS X: opensearchserver-1.4.zip Pour Linux, Solaris, Unix: opensearchserver-1.4.tar.gz Suivi des modifications: CHANGELOG.txt Tous les fichiers: Librairies JAVA, PHP et ASP.NET Précédente version stable: v1.2.4 Pour Windows, Mac OS X: open-search-server-1.2.4.zip Pour Linux, Solaris, Unix: open-search-server-1.2.4.tar.gz Suivi des modifications: CHANGELOG.txt Tous les fichiers: Librairies JAVA, PHP et ASP.NET Principes de versioning Version actuelle stable et certifiée La stabilité est un jugement subjectif et nous vous conseillons toujours de lire attentivement le change log txt. Les versions stables peuvent contenir un petit nombre de bugs mineurs. La version stable est adaptée aux environnements de production qui réclament stabilité et qui vont fonctionner sur des longues périodes de temps. Version Beta La version Beta peut contenir des fonctionnalités non encore testées et/ou un certain nombre de bugs relativement mineurs. Il se peut qu’une version Beta puisse être instable sur la durée. Version Alpha La version Alpha peut contenir un certain nombre de fonctionnalités non encore testées ou manquantes mais inscrites dans les spécifications et des bugs significatifs. On ne peut attendre d’une version Alpha aucune notion de stabilité dans la durée. Documentation Dans la documentation vous trouverez des tutoriels, des guides d’installation et des manuels de référence . Le wiki est la source principale d’information. Il contient des contributions de la communauté d’utilisateur et des développeurs. Nos forums Sollicitez l’aide de la communauté dans le forum d’aide . La réponse que vous attendez y est peut-être déjà. Participez au bouillonnement d’Open Search Server en ouvrant de nouveaux sujets de discussion . Voir l’ensemble de nos forums Evolutions et bugs Le système de suivi vous permet de signaler tout dysfonctionnement, de proposer de nouvelles fonctionnalités, et de suivre l’évolution de vos demandes. Reporter un dysfonctionnement . Proposer une nouvelle fonctionnalité . Code source L’accès au code source se fait via Subversion. Suivez les instructions de SourceForge pour l’accès au code source . Canal IRC Le canal IRC OpenSearchServer est un chat en direct avec la communauté d’utilisateurs et les experts d’OpenSearchServer. Serveur IRC: chat.freenode.net - Canal: #OpenSearchServer Pour plus d’information sur ce qu’est IRC (Internet Relay Chat): http://www.irchelp.org/ Vous pouvez utiliser votre propre client IRC ou notre page web . Réseaux sociaux Tweets concernant "#opensearchserve OR opensearchserver OR "open search server" OR jaeksoft" Informations légales © 2013 OpenSearchServer Responsive Theme Propulsé par WordPress

Support Center Saas Center Monitoring Center Accueil Fonctionnalités Offres et tarifs Documentation Communauté Newsletter Contact A propos Presse Offres et tarifs L’offre SaaS Un service de location d’une instance OpenSearchServer hébergée sur notre propre infrastructure Cloud. Cette offre vous permet de disposer en quelques minutes du logiciel OpenSearchServer complet et opérationnel via son interface utilisateur et ses APIs. L’infrastructure Cloud d’OpenSearchServer est supervisée en 24/7, 365 jours par an, pour garantir un taux de disponibilité optimum. Découvrez comment mettre en oeuvre une instance OpenSearchServer SaaS sur notre plateforme Cloud. Formules FREE BETA DISCOVER EVOLUTION ADVANCED PROFESSIONAL ENTERPRISE Nombre de documents 200 1 000 10 000 100 000 1 million 10 millions Nombre d’index 5 5 10 100 Illimité Illimité Stockage 200 Mo 500 Mo 2 Go 5 Go 20 Go 50 Go Requêtes par mois 5 000 10 000 50 000 250 000 500 000 Illimité Performance (api / seconde) 20 100 500 1000 Illimité Illimité Prix par mois (1) Gratuit 9 ,90 € 19 ,90 € 39 ,90 € 79 ,90 € 149 ,00 € 14 jours d’essai gratuit Services de support Nous fournissons des services de support et d’assistance pour les intégrateurs et utilisateurs d’OpenSearchServer. De sa planification jusqu’à sa mise en ligne, nous sommes à vos côtés pour garantir le succès de vos projets et l’atteinte de vos objectifs. Formules COMMUNITY PROFESSIONAL ENTERPRISE Ouverture d’incident (par email ou par l’interface web) Illimité Illimité Illimité Plage de support 9h-19h 5j/7 24h/24 7j/7 24h/24 7j/7 Temps de réponse maximal 1 jour ouvré 8 heures 4 heures Support technique Oui Oui Oui Support fonctionnel Non Oui (Heures ouvrées) Oui (24×7) Nombre de contacts 1 1 3 Intervention à distance Non Non Oui Monitoring actif & alertes 1 instance 3 instances 10 instances Prix pour un an 490 € 990 € 2 990 € Notre équipe est à votre disposition pour répondre à toutes vos questions. Contactez-nous via le formulaire de contact ou en nous écrivant à contact@open-search-server.com . (1) Sans engagement: Vous pouvez stopper l’abonnement à tout moment. Toute commande suppose l’acceptation sans réserve des conditions générales des ventes . Support Center SaaS Center Monitoring Center Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Pricing SaaS services Our Saas offer is an OpenSearchServer instance rental based on our own Cloud infrastructure. With this offer, you get access in several minutes to a fully and operational OpenSearchServer solution with its user interface and its APIs. OpenSearchServer Cloud infrastructure is monitored on 24X7, 365 days per year, in order to guarantee you with high optimized availability. Discover how to set up an OpenSearchServer SaaS instance on our Cloud platform. 14 day free trial Plans FREE BETA DISCOVER EVOLUTION ADVANCED PROFESSIONAL ENTERPRISE Number of documents 200 1,000 10,000 100,000 1 million 10 millions Index number 5 5 10 100 Unlimited Unlimited Storage 200 MB 500 MB 2 GB 5 GB 20 GB 50 GB API requests per month 5,000 10,000 50,000 250,000 500,000 Unlimited API performance (requests per second) 20 100 500 1,000 Unlimited Unlimited Price per month (1) Free € 9 .90 € 19 .90 € 39 .90 € 79 .90 € 149 .00 Support services We provide support and services for OpenSearchServer users. From the planning process through completion of the project, we will assist you to deliver your project on time and meet all your objectives. Plans COMMUNITY PROFESSIONAL ENTERPRISE E-mail support Web tickets Unlimited Unlimited Unlimited Time slot 9am-7pm Mon-Fri 24×7 24×7 Maximum response time 1 working day 8 hours 4 hours Number of contacts 1 1 3 Technical support Yes Yes Yes Functional support No Yes (working hours) Yes (24×7) Remote maintenance No No Yes Active Monitoring & Alerting tool 1 instance 3 instances 10 instances Price for one year € 490 € 990 € 2,990 Our team remains available to answer your questions. Use our contact form or send us an email at contact@open-search-server.com . (1) No commitment: You pay on a monthly basis. Quit whenever you like, no advance notice. Each order implies the acceptance without reserve of the General terms and conditions. What is Query Filters? The query filter or filter query that is used to filter the documents returned to particular value. This will be useful while filtering the facet values. Any number of filters can be used in single HTTP request. Example filter using HTTP request : http://localhost:8080/oss_1.3/select?use=index&qt=search&q=opensearchserver& fq=color:red Example filter using OpenSearchServer interface: color:red Adding an query filter Query - The query that need to be filtered for the current query template. Example : url:" http://www.open-search-server.com " The double quotes in case of URL is important. Negative- Performs a negative query. Matches all the documents other than the filter. Add - Add the query filter . Enter the query and check if the query need to perform an negative query. Click the add button to add the query filter. Range query OpenSearchServer also allows user to perform range query too. Example : http://localhost:8080/oss_1.3/select?use=index&qt=search&q=opensearchserver&fq=year:[2000 TO 2012] Geo Filter query Lets assume we have the latitude and longitude of and need to find the product or any related thing in and around 5 or 10km. The Geo Filter can be used. Adding an Geo Filter To add the Geo filter select the type as squared. Distance unit - Distance can be in Kilometers,Meters,Miles,Feet. Distance - Distance that need to be searched around. Latitude Field - The field in which the latitude are stored. Longitude field - The field in which the longitude are stored. Latitude (lat) - The latitude that need to be searched. Longitude (lon) - The longitude that need to be searched. Location unit - The location units in radians or degrees. Click the add button to add the Geo filter.

How report module works? Reports are generated thought the log files. The select API is used to create custom log values. The logX parameter contanins the custom value that will be added in the log. The X is an numerical value ranges from 0-9. The log=1 parameter enables the log generation for current request. Example using HTTP request http://localhost:8080/search?use=oss&qt=search&q=test&log=1&log1=myemailid&log2=myname Example using PHP client $search = new OssSearch(OSS_PATH, OSS_INDEX_NAME, OSS_RESULT_PER_PAGE, $start); $search->setLog(true); $search->setCustomLog(1, session_id()); $search->setCustomLog (2, “testuser”); $search->setCustomLog (3, $_SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR']); Log File format The logfile is an ASCII text field. Fields are seperated with a tabulation character. Default log fields. Field Description Date The Commom W3c log format Eg:[18/01/2913:23:29:47 +0100] Keyword The key word that has been searched,Which is URL encoded in UTF8. Duration A numerical value of the time taken to search. Count A numerical value of the total number of result returned from the search engine. Start A numerical value of the start value. Custom values The custom values that are passed by the Select API(URL Encoded in UTF8). Log files will be stored in the existing log folder. [OpenSearchServer installation folder]/data/logs/ The log files are rotated.The pattern for the rotated log files is report.[index name].YYYY-MM-DD How to create a report? Enter the keyword to search. By default the search keyword will be *:*. Selec the query type. There are two types of queries Top Queries - This will return the top queries from the loaded reports which is based on the frequency. Top Queries with no result - This will return the top queries with zero result from the loaded reports which is based on the frequency. Select the Begin date and End date. Enter the number of queries to be displayed. Click the Create Report button. A list of Top keywords and its frequency will be displayed. Click the Export Report button to export the returned search result as CSV file.

Description Use this API to get monitoring information about your OpenSearchServer instance. http://{server_name}:{port}/{application_path}/services/rest/monitor/{json|xml}?login={login}&key={api_key}&full={true|false} Example of HTTP request http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/monitor/xml?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f&full=true http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/monitor/json?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f&full=false Request example using CURL curl 'http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/monitor/xml?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f&full=false' curl 'http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/monitor/json?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f&full=false' API result The API returns the monitoring information either in XML or JSON format <result successful="true"> <basic availableProcessors="4" freeMemory="931579248" memoryRate="87.47013254713171" maxMemory="1065025536" totalMemory="1065025536" indexCount="21" freeDiskSpace="51432013824" freeDiskRate="10.060043103102943"/> </result> { "result": { "@successful": "true", "basic": { "@availableProcessors": "4", "@freeMemory": "940630152", "@memoryRate": "88.31996231121354", "@maxMemory": "1065025536", "@totalMemory": "1065025536", "@indexCount": "21", "@freeDiskSpace": "51431731200", "@freeDiskRate": "10.05998782217166" } } }

Examples HTTP Request http://localhost:8080/webcrawler?use=index1&action=start http://localhost:8080/webcrawler?use=index1&action=stop Http Response <response> <entry key="info">STARTED</entry> <entry key="status">OK</entry> </response> Description The web crawler API performs following actions starts or stops,the web crawler Parameters List Parameters Description use It is the index name login (optional) The login parameter. This is required once you create a user. key (optional) The key parameter related to the login (api key). This is required once you create a user. action The action to perform: start, stop, and know status of the index. runOnce The runOnce parameter is to specify the crawler should run only once or forever. This is an boolean parameter.

Description Use this API to insert documents in an index. http://{server_name}:{port}/{application_path}/services/rest/update/{index_name}/{json|xml}?login={login}&key={api_key} This API use the HTTP method POST. You can either post a document in XML format or in JSON format. Example of HTTP request http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/update/myindex/xml?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/update/myindex/json?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f Request example using CURL curl -X POST -H 'content-type: application/xml' 'http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/update/myindex/xml?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f' -d '<documents> <document lang="ENGLISH"> <value field="uri">http://www.open-search-server.com</value> <value field="title">Homepage</value> </document> </documents>' curl -X POST -H 'content-type: application/json' 'http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/update/myindex/json?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f' -d '{ "documents": {"document": [ { "@lang": "ENGLISH", "value": [ { "@field": "uri", "$": "http://www.open-search-server.com/" }, { "@field": "title", "$": "Homepage" } ] } ] } }' Document format The documents you want to insert in the index can either being describe in XML or JSON format. One request can contains several documents. Here is a minimalist example with a document containing two fields ( uri and title ). The language of the document is defined in the lang attribute. The possible values are: UNDEFINED, ARABIC, CHINESE, DANISH, DUTCH, ENGLISH, FINNISH, FRENCH, GERMAN, HUNGARIAN, ITALIAN, JAPANESE, KOREAN, NORWEGIAN, PORTUGUESE, ROMANIAN, RUSSIAN, SPANISH, SWEDISH, TURKISH. <documents> <document lang="ENGLISH"> <value field="uri">http://www.open-search-server.com/</value> <value field="title">Title</value> </document> </documents> It is possible to insert several values for one field. Both XML and JSON formats provide an easy way to do that. In this example, the field content will contains two values "Content1" and "Content2". The second value will be boosted by a factor 2. <documents> <document lang="ENGLISH"> <value field="uri" boost="1.0">http://www.open-search-server.com/</value> <value field="title">Title</value> <values field="content" boost="1.0"> <value>Content1</value> <value boost="2.0">Content2</value> </values> </document> </documents> More example { "documents": { "document": [ { "@lang": "ENGLISH", "value": [ { "@field": "id", "$": "1" }, { "@field": "title", "$": "First document" } ] }, { "@lang": "ENGLISH", "value": [ { "@field": "id", "$": "2" }, { "@field": "title", "$": "Second document" } ] } ] } } { "documents": { "document": [ { "@lang": "ENGLISH", "value": [ { "@field": "uri", "@boost": "1.0", "$": "http://www.open-search-server.com/" }, { "@field": "title", "$": "Title" } ], "values": [ { "@field": "content", "@boost": "1.0", "value": [ { "$": "Content1" }, { "@boost": "2.0", "$": "Content2" } ] } ] } ] } } API result { "result": { "successful":true, "info":"2 document(s) updated" } } <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?> <result successful="true"> <info>1 document(s) updated</info> </result>

Description Use this API to insert documents in an index. http://{server_name}:{port}/{application_path}/services/rest/update/{index_name}/{json|xml}?login={login}&key={api_key} This API use the HTTP method POST. You can either post a document in XML format or in JSON format. Example of HTTP request http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/update/myindex/xml?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/update/myindex/json?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f Request example using CURL curl -X POST -H 'content-type: application/xml' 'http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/update/myindex/xml?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f' -d '<documents> <document lang="ENGLISH"> <value field="uri">http://www.open-search-server.com</value> <value field="title">Homepage</value> </document> </documents>' curl -X POST -H 'content-type: application/json' 'http://localhost:8080/oss-1.4/services/rest/update/myindex/json?login=username&key=5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f' -d '{ "documents": {"document": [ { "@lang": "ENGLISH", "value": [ { "@field": "uri", "$": "http://www.open-search-server.com/" }, { "@field": "title", "$": "Homepage" } ] } ] } }' Document format The documents you want to insert in the index can either being describe in XML or JSON format. One request can contains several documents. Here is a minimalist example with a document containing two fields ( uri and title ). The language of the document is defined in the lang attribute. The possible values are: UNDEFINED, ARABIC, CHINESE, DANISH, DUTCH, ENGLISH, FINNISH, FRENCH, GERMAN, HUNGARIAN, ITALIAN, JAPANESE, KOREAN, NORWEGIAN, PORTUGUESE, ROMANIAN, RUSSIAN, SPANISH, SWEDISH, TURKISH. <documents> <document lang="ENGLISH"> <value field="uri">http://www.open-search-server.com/</value> <value field="title">Title</value> </document> </documents> It is possible to insert several values for one field. Both XML and JSON formats provide an easy way to do that. In this example, the field content will contains two values "Content1" and "Content2". The second value will be boosted by a factor 2. <documents> <document lang="ENGLISH"> <value field="uri" boost="1.0">http://www.open-search-server.com/</value> <value field="title">Title</value> <values field="content" boost="1.0"> <value>Content1</value> <value boost="2.0">Content2</value> </values> </document> </documents> More example { "documents": { "document": [ { "@lang": "ENGLISH", "value": [ { "@field": "id", "$": "1" }, { "@field": "title", "$": "First document" } ] }, { "@lang": "ENGLISH", "value": [ { "@field": "id", "$": "2" }, { "@field": "title", "$": "Second document" } ] } ] } } { "documents": { "document": [ { "@lang": "ENGLISH", "value": [ { "@field": "uri", "@boost": "1.0", "$": "http://www.open-search-server.com/" }, { "@field": "title", "$": "Title" } ], "values": [ { "@field": "content", "@boost": "1.0", "value": [ { "$": "Content1" }, { "@boost": "2.0", "$": "Content2" } ] } ] } ] } } API result { "result": { "successful":true, "info":"2 document(s) updated" } } <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?> <result successful="true"> <info>1 document(s) updated</info> </result>

Support Center Saas Center Monitoring Center Accueil Fonctionnalités Offres et tarifs Documentation Communauté Newsletter Contact A propos Presse OpenSearchServer 1.3 et version SaaS Posté le 25 octobre 2012 par Jaeksoft COMMUNIQUE DE PRESSE OpenSearchServer, le premier moteur de recherche open source en version SaaS en Europe s’enrichit de 30 nouvelles fonctionnalités PARIS – 25 octobre 2012 – La startup française Jaeksoft éditeur du moteur de recherche open source OpenSearchServer lance la nouvelle version de son logiciel. OpenSearchServer est maintenant disponible en SaaS. Grâce à cette offre, il est possible de doter rapidement et facilement son site Internet d’un moteur de recherche à l’état de l’art. Son intégration dans les sites e-commerce et sites de contenus n’a jamais été aussi aisée. Plus de 30 nouvelles fonctionnalités permettent à OpenSearchServer 1.3 de se hisser au niveau des meilleures offres concurrentes: Intégration d’un OCR appliqué aux PDF et aux images, la détection et l’indexation des vidéos YouTube(tm), Dailymotion(tm), Vimeo(tm), le support de la phonétique, l’indexation des fichiers Dropbox(tm), la recherche géo-localisée, la reconnaissance d’entités nommées, les suggestions automatiques, la catégorisation automatique, les web services REST/JSON et SOAP , l’intégration avec WordPress(tm) et Drupal(tm). « Cette nouvelle étape est le témoin de notre engagement pour l’innovation. Il s’agit du premier élément d’un programme d’innovation lancé en 2011 avec le soutien d’OSEO. » déclare Emmanuel Keller fondateur et directeur technique de la jeune société. Contact presse: Jaeksoft – OpenSearchServer Emmanuel Keller - Hugues Burghard contact@open-search-server.com Télécharger la version PDF ‹ OpenSearchServer, magazine Challenges Publié dans Communiqués de presse dans les archives octobre 2012 juin 2012 juin 2011 Réseaux sociaux Tweets concernant "#opensearchserve OR opensearchserver OR "open search server" OR jaeksoft" Informations légales © 2013 OpenSearchServer Responsive Theme Propulsé par WordPress

Support Center Saas Center Monitoring Center Accueil Fonctionnalités Offres et tarifs Documentation Communauté Newsletter Contact A propos Presse OpenSearchServer, magazine Challenges Posté le 7 juin 2012 par Jaeksoft COMMUNIQUE DE PRESSE Jaeksoft OpenSearchServer a été choisi par Challenges pour faire partie des 100 start-up françaises où investir PARIS – 7 juin 2012 – Jaeksoft éditeur du moteur de recherche Open Source OpenSearchServer a été sélectionné par le magazine Challenges dans son numéro hebdomadaire n°304 du 07 au 13 juin 2012 pour faire partie des 100 startups dans lesquelles il faut investir. « Cette reconnaissance par un acteur incontournable de la presse économique française ne peut que renforcer notre volonté de développement » déclare Emmanuel Keller fondateur et directeur technique de la jeune société. OpenSearchServer annonce sa première levée | OpenSearchServer

Support Center Saas Center Monitoring Center Accueil Fonctionnalités Offres et tarifs Documentation Communauté Newsletter Contact A propos Presse OpenSearchServer annonce sa première levée Posté le 29 juin 2011 par Jaeksoft COMMUNIQUE DE PRESSE OpenSearchServer, solution de search pour sites et applications annonce sa première levée PARIS – 29 juin 2011 – OpenSearchServer développe un logiciel open source permettant de créer des applications comme par exemple un moteur de recherche indexant des données pour des recherches sur un site web ou des bases documentaires. L’éditeur a alors la main sur la pertinence de son moteur. La société propose de façon générale une solution à toute entreprise ayant à gérer des problématiques de données. Parmi les fonctionnalités d’OpenSearchServer: Création d’applications sophistiquées sans écriture de la moindre ligne de code Accès total au contrôle et à la personnalisation des algorithmes Implémentation d’OpenSearchServer dans tout type d’applications La société vient de réaliser sa première levée en amorçage auprès de Kima Ventures, Jacques- Antoine Granjon, (Vente-privee.com), Fabrice Grinda (Olx.com) et Jose Marin (Serendipity). Contact presse: Jaeksoft – OpenSearchServer Emmanuel Keller - Hugues Burghard contact@open-search-server.com Téléchargez la version PDF OpenSearchServer, magazine Challenges › Publié dans Communiqués de presse dans les archives octobre 2012 juin 2012 juin 2011 Réseaux sociaux Tweets concernant "#opensearchserve OR opensearchserver OR "open search server" OR jaeksoft" Informations légales © 2013 OpenSearchServer Responsive Theme Propulsé par WordPress

This line was removed. Formatting was changed. ... Variable Example Description server_name localhost The hostname of your OpenSearchServer instance port 8080 The TCP port of your server (on a SaaS instance it can be 80) application_path If you use the OpenSearchServer package, it may be /. If you are using a SaaS instance it can be some like /1679091c-5a88-3faf-afb5-e6087eb1b2dc index_name myindex The name of the index (it must be URL encoded). The monitor API don't need an index name. function_name update The name of the function. Usualy: update, search, delete, monitor... json|xml json The format which will be use for the reply and to upload data login myname If you have created a user in your OpenSearchServer instance this is the username (it must be URL encoded) api_key 5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f The API key to use for authentication (available in the Privileges tab panel of OpenSearchServer) API result If the API call is successful, the returned HTTP code will be 200. The API will also return some information either in XML or JSON format depending of your request.   Code Block title JSON result language none { "result": { "successful":true, "info":"..." } } Code Block title XML result language html/xml ... In case of failure, an appropriate HTTP error code will be sent. The body will contains more information in HTML format. Code Block title Failure message language html/xml Apache Tomcat/7.0.35 - Error report

HTTP Status 500 - org.apache.cxf.interceptor.Fault: com.jaeksoft.searchlib.SearchLibException: The unique value is missing (uri)

type Exception report

message org.apache.cxf.interceptor.Fault: com.jaeksoft.searchlib.SearchLibException: The unique value is missing (uri)

description The server encountered an internal error that prevented it from fulfilling this request.

exception 

java.lang.RuntimeException: org.apache.cxf.interceptor.Fault: com.jaeksoft.searchlib.SearchLibException: The unique value is missing (uri) org.apache.cxf.interceptor.AbstractFaultChainInitiatorObserver.onMessage(AbstractFaultChainInitiatorObserver.java:117) org.apache.cxf.phase.PhaseInterceptorChain.doIntercept(PhaseInterceptorChain.java:331) org.apache.cxf.transport.ChainInitiationObserver.onMessage(ChainInitiationObserver.java:121) org.apache.cxf.transport.http.AbstractHTTPDestination.invoke(AbstractHTTPDestination.java:239) ... RESTful API: Update - English - OpenSearchServer documentation

Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Need more help ? Take a look at our support services Starting at €79 for one month. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home RESTful API RESTful API: Update Tools A ttachments (0) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source RESTful API: Update Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Added by Emmanuel Keller , last edited by Emmanuel Keller on Feb 18, 2013 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata Description Use this API to insert documents in an index. Call syntax This API use the HTTP method POST. You can either post a document in XML format or in JSON format. Example of HTTP request Example of XML call Example of JSON call Request example using CURL Posting a document using CURL and XML Posting a document using CURL and JSON Document format The documents you want to insert in the index can either being describe in XML or JSON format. One request can contains several documents. Here is a minimalist example with a document containing two fields ( uri and title ). The language of the document is defined in the lang attribute. The possible values are: UNDEFINED, ARABIC, CHINESE, DANISH, DUTCH, ENGLISH, FINNISH, FRENCH, GERMAN, HUNGARIAN, ITALIAN, JAPANESE, KOREAN, NORWEGIAN, PORTUGUESE, ROMANIAN, RUSSIAN, SPANISH, SWEDISH, TURKISH. Inserting a document using XML It is possible to insert several values for one field. Both XML and JSON formats provide an easy way to do that. In this example, the field content will contains two values "Content1" and "Content2". The second value will be boosted by a factor 2. Inserting 2 documents using XML More example Inserting 2 documents using JSON Inserting one document using JSON API result JSON result XML result Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Inline help - Query - Filters - English - OpenSearchServer documentation

Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Need more help ? Take a look at our support services Starting at €79 for one month. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home Inline Help Query Inline help - Query - Filters Tools A ttachments (0) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Inline help - Query - Filters Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Feb 15, 2013 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata What is Query Filters? The query filter or filter query that is used to filter the documents returned to particular value. This will be useful while filtering the facet values. Any number of filters can be used in single HTTP request. Example filter using HTTP request : http://localhost:8080/oss_1.3/select?use=index&qt=search&q=opensearchserver& fq=color:red Example filter using OpenSearchServer interface: color:red Adding an query filter Query - The query that need to be filtered for the current query template. Example : url:" http://www.open-search-server.com " The double quotes in case of URL is important. Negative- Performs a negative query. Matches all the documents other than the filter. Add - Add the query filter . Enter the query and check if the query need to perform an negative query. Click the add button to add the query filter. Range query OpenSearchServer also allows user to perform range query too. Example : http://localhost:8080/oss_1.3/select?use=index&qt=search&q=opensearchserver&fq=year:[2000 TO 2012] Geo Filter query Lets assume we have the latitude and longitude of and need to find the product or any related thing in and around 5 or 10km. The Geo Filter can be used. Adding an Geo Filter To add the Geo filter select the type as squared. Distance unit - Distance can be in Kilometers,Meters,Miles,Feet. Distance - Distance that need to be searched around. Latitude Field - The field in which the latitude are stored. Longitude field - The field in which the longitude are stored. Latitude (lat) - The latitude that need to be searched. Longitude (lon) - The longitude that need to be searched. Location unit - The location units in radians or degrees. Click the add button to add the Geo filter. Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Evaluate Confluence today . Powered by Atlassian Confluence 4.3.5 , the Enterprise Wiki Printed by Atlassian Confluence 4.3.5, the Enterprise Wiki. · Report a bug · Atlassian News

Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Need more help ? Take a look at our support services Starting at €79 for one month. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home Inline Help Renderer Inline help - Renderer - Log Tools A ttachments (0) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Inline help - Renderer - Log Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Jan 17, 2013 Go to start of metadata Logs can be enabled and custom logs can also be generated by log tab. To enable the logging just select the Enable Logs Checkbox. Click Save or Save&Close to save the action. How to add custom fields to log file? CustomLog The custom log field ranges from 0-9. which can be mapped to some parameter. Parameters A list of parameters are available to map with the custom fields. IP - Returns the IP adress of the client. HTTP_HEADER_FROM - Returns the login of the user making this request, if the user has been authenticated HTTP_HEADER_REMOTE_USER - Returns the name of the current authenticated user. USER_SESSION_ID - Returns the current user session ID. Select the Custom log and corresponding Parameter that need to be mapped and click + button. A new fields will be added in the list below. Click Save or Save&Close to save the added custom log fields. Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Evaluate Confluence today . Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home Inline Help Reports Inline help - Reports - LogFiles Tools A ttachments (0) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Inline help - Reports - LogFiles Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Jan 17, 2013 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata Load, Archive, Delete reports A list of available log files will be displayed which can be loaded,archived and deleted. The list contains the below details. File Name - The name of the file from the log directory. Date - The timestamp when the log has been created. On clicking the Load button is click the log file will be loaded in the index. On clicking the Archive button the log file will be archieved and removed from the list. On clicking the Delete button the log file will be removed from the list and the filesystem. Inline help - Reports - Query Reports - English - OpenSearchServer documentation

Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Need more help ? Take a look at our support services Starting at €79 for one month. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home Inline Help Reports Inline help - Reports - Query Reports Tools A ttachments (0) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Inline help - Reports - Query Reports Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Jan 17, 2013 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata How report module works? Reports are generated thought the log files. The select API is used to create custom log values. The logX parameter contanins the custom value that will be added in the log. The X is an numerical value ranges from 0-9. The log=1 parameter enables the log generation for current request. Example using HTTP request Example using PHP client Log File format The logfile is an ASCII text field. Fields are seperated with a tabulation character. Default log fields. Field Description Date The Commom W3c log format Eg:[18/01/2913:23:29:47 +0100] Keyword The key word that has been searched,Which is URL encoded in UTF8. Duration A numerical value of the time taken to search. Count A numerical value of the total number of result returned from the search engine. Start A numerical value of the start value. Custom values The custom values that are passed by the Select API(URL Encoded in UTF8). Log files will be stored in the existing log folder. [OpenSearchServer installation folder]/data/logs/ The log files are rotated.The pattern for the rotated log files is report.[index name].YYYY-MM-DD How to create a report? Enter the keyword to search. By default the search keyword will be *:*. Selec the query type. There are two types of queries Top Queries - This will return the top queries from the loaded reports which is based on the frequency. Top Queries with no result - This will return the top queries with zero result from the loaded reports which is based on the frequency. Select the Begin date and End date. Enter the number of queries to be displayed. Click the Create Report button. A list of Top keywords and its frequency will be displayed. Click the Export Report button to export the returned search result as CSV file. Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Reports are generated thought the log files. The select API is used to create custom log values. The logX parameter contanins the custom value that will be added in the log. The X is an numerical value ranges from 0-9. The log=1 parameter enables the log generation for current request. Example using HTTP request Example using PHP client Log File format The logfile is an ASCII text field. Fields are seperated with a tabulation character. Default log fields. Field Description Date The Commom W3c log format Eg:[18/01/2913:23:29:47 +0100] Keyword The key word that has been searched,Which is URL encoded in UTF8. Duration A numerical value of the time taken to search. Count A numerical value of the total number of result returned from the search engine. Start A numerical value of the start value. Custom values The custom values that are passed by the Select API(URL Encoded in UTF8). Log files will be stored in the existing log folder. [OpenSearchServer installation folder]/data/logs/ The log files are rotated.The pattern for the rotated log files is report.[index name].YYYY-MM-DD How to create a report? Enter the keyword to search. By default the search keyword will be *:*. Selec the query type. There are two types of queries Top Queries - This will return the top queries from the loaded reports which is based on the frequency. Top Queries with no result - This will return the top queries with zero result from the loaded reports which is based on the frequency. Select the Begin date and End date. Enter the number of queries to be displayed. Click the Create Report button. A list of Top keywords and its frequency will be displayed. Click the Export Report button to export the returned search result as CSV file. Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Configuring OpenSearchServer in Eclipse - English - OpenSearchServer documentation

Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Need more help ? Take a look at our support services Starting at €79 for one month. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home FAQ Configuring OpenSearchServer in Eclipse Tools A ttachments (15) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Configuring OpenSearchServer in Eclipse Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Attachments: 15 Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Jan 17, 2013 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata Prerequisite for OpenSearchServer1.3 Eclipse J2EE (Juno or newer) with SVN and ZK plugin installed. Apache Tomcat 6.x.x. Apache CFX 2.6.x. Dynamic web module version 2.5 Prerequisite for OpenSearchServer1.4 Eclipse J2EE (Juno or newer) with SVN and ZK plugin installed. Apache Tomcat 7.x.x. Apache CFX 2.7.x. Dynamic web module version 3.0 Configuring OpenSearchServer From the context menu select File / Import. Select the Project from SVN. The current stable version of OpenSearchServer is 1.3 so we are using that version for this tutorial. The SVN URL is http://svn.code.sf.net/p/opensearchserve/code/branches/1.3/ . Click Finish A new dialog will appear. Select the Check our as a project configured using the New Project Wizard. Make other things as default and click next. A new dialog to select the new project type will appear. Select the Dynamic Web Project and click next. While Selecting the source folder. By default src folder will be there. Select the folder and Remove it. Click Add Folder... to add new source folder. Add src/java and src/resources to the source folder. Click Next . Unselect the Generate web.xml deployment descriptor option and click Finish. Eclipse will start checking out the project. Configuring tomcat server. In the servers tab by default there wont be any servers. Click the new server wizard.. to define new server. Select the Apache Tomcat v6.0 Server and click Next . Enter the location of tomcat directory and click F inish . Right click the project in Project Explorer and Select RunAs / Run Configuration . And add the Environmental variable. The data directory can be any empty directory. Right Click the project and select Properties. Click the project facets and add CFX and ZK studio support . Right click the project and Run As / Run on Server. OpenSearchServer will be started in http://localhost:8080 Building OpenSearchServer with ant Once the project has been setup in eclipse you can build the project using ant. Right click the build.xml and select RunAs / AntBuild . The build process will be started. The console will give the BUILD SUCCESSFUL message. A new directory named dist will be found which has all the OpenSearchServer build packages. Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Evaluate Confluence today . Powered by Atlassian Confluence 4.3.5 , the Enterprise Wiki Printed by Atlassian Confluence 4.3.5, the Enterprise Wiki. · Report a bug · Atlassian News

Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home RESTful API Tools A ttachments (0) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source RESTful API Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Added by Emmanuel Keller , last edited by Emmanuel Keller on Feb 18, 2013 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata OpenSearchServer 1.4 introduces a new RESTful API. This new API supports both XML and JSON. Common API syntax Call syntax Variable Example Description server_name localhost The hostname of your OpenSearchServer instance port 8080 The TCP port of your server (on a SaaS instance it can be 80) application_path If you use the OpenSearchServer package, it may be /. If you are using a SaaS instance it can be some like /1679091c-5a88-3faf-afb5-e6087eb1b2dc index_name myindex The name of the index (it must be URL encoded). The monitor API don't need an index name. function_name update The name of the function. Usualy: update, search, delete, monitor... json|xml json The format which will be use for the reply and to upload data login myname If you have created a user in your OpenSearchServer instance this is the username (it must be URL encoded) api_key 5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f The API key to use for authentication (available in the Privileges tab panel of OpenSearchServer) API result If the API call is successful, the returned HTTP code will be 200. The API will also return some information either in XML or JSON format depending of your request. JSON result XML result In case of failure, an appropriate HTTP error code will be sent. The body will contains more information in HTML format. Failure message Labels None 2 Child Pages Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Evaluate Confluence today . Powered by Atlassian Confluence 4.3.5 , the Enterprise Wiki Printed by Atlassian Confluence 4.3.5, the Enterprise Wiki. · Report a bug · Atlassian News

This new API supports both XML and JSON. Common API syntax Call syntax Variable Example Description server_name localhost The hostname of your OpenSearchServer instance port 8080 The TCP port of your server (on a SaaS instance it can be 80) application_path If you use the OpenSearchServer package, it may be /. If you are using a SaaS instance it can be some like /1679091c-5a88-3faf-afb5-e6087eb1b2dc index_name myindex The name of the index (it must be URL encoded). The monitor API don't need an index name. function_name update The name of the function. Usualy: update, search, delete, monitor... json|xml json The format which will be use for the reply and to upload data login myname If you have created a user in your OpenSearchServer instance this is the username (it must be URL encoded) api_key 5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f The API key to use for authentication (available in the Privileges tab panel of OpenSearchServer) API result If the API call is successful, the returned HTTP code will be 200. The API will also return some information either in XML or JSON format depending of your request. JSON result XML result In case of failure, an appropriate HTTP error code will be sent. The body will contains more information in HTML format. Failure message Labels None 2 Child Pages Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. The permanent link to access the SaaS Center in order to manage your OpenSearchServer instance. The access link to Support Center to communicate with our technical support team. Click on "Start" button to start the instance. Congratulations! Your OpenSearchServer instance is now working. Click on "View" button to access to its web interface. Support Center Saas Center Monitoring Center Accueil Fonctionnalités Offres et tarifs Documentation Communauté Newsletter Contact A propos Presse Fonctionnalités OpenSearchServer est un moteur de recherche et un crawler open source basé sur les meilleures technologies open source. Fonctions de recherche Fonctions avancées de recherche full-text Recherche phonétique Recherche booléenne avancée avec langage de requêtes Facettes avec comptages Filtres basés sur des sous-requêtes (filtre négatif inclus) Géolocalisation Correction orthographique Personnalisation de la pertinence Suggestion automatique (auto-completion) Parsers Les parsers reconnaissent les fichiers à indexer en se basant sur leur extension ou le type MIME, ils extraient automatiquement les informations nécessaires à l’indexation (titre, texte, auteur, liens hypertexte, etc.). De nombreux formats sont supportés: HTML / XHTML, MS Office (Word, Excel, Powerpoint), Documents OpenOffice, Adobe PDF (avec OCR), RTF, Plaintext, Fichiers audios (WAV, MP3, AIFF, OGG/Vorbis) Fichier Torrent, OCR sur fichier images Divers API REST (XML et JSON) Web Service SOAP Librairies clientes PHP et .NET Outils de supervision Réplication d’index (haute disponibilité) Ordonnanceur intégré pour la gestion de tâches complexes Plugin WordPress et module Drupal Indexation 17 langages supportés Définition du schéma d’indexation et des analyseurs par champs et pour chaque langue Outils semantiques: n-gram, lemmatisation multilingue, singles, caractères accentués, … Détection automatique de la langue Identification d’entités nommées Synonymes de mots et expressions Export des vocabulaires de termes et leurs fréquences Crawlers Ce module prend en charge l’indexation des données. OpenSearchServer est équipé de plusieurs crawlers spécialisés qui permettent de parcourir et d’indexer différentes catégories de contenus: Le crawler Web pour les sites Internet, extranet and intranet, Les systèmes de fichiers locaux et distants (NFS, SMB/CIFS, FTP, FTPS), L’indexation de base de données JDBC (MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, SQL Server, …). Chaque crawler dispose de paramètres personnalisés: Liste d’inclusion et d’exclusion utilisant les caractères génériques (wildcards) Suppression automatique des paramètres de session Support des jointures SQL et des pièces jointes Captures d’écran Import de sitemap Réseaux sociaux Tweets concernant "#opensearchserve OR opensearchserver OR "open search server" OR jaeksoft" Informations légales © 2013 OpenSearchServer Responsive Theme Propulsé par WordPress

Support Center Saas Center Monitoring Center Accueil Fonctionnalités Offres et tarifs Documentation Communauté Newsletter Contact A propos Presse A propos Emmanuel Keller Directeur technique Hugues Burghard Directeur commercial Dr Serguei Victorov Responsable R&D Naveen.A.N Développement et qualité Le projet OpenSearchServer est né en 2007 au sein d’ Infopro Communications , un groupe d’information et de services professionnels français couvrant cinq secteurs clés de l’économie au travers de logiciels, bases de données, services en ligne, magazines, salons, formations, conférences. Parce qu’il n’existait pas de solution de recherche offrant à la fois, des fonctionnalités complètes, un prix compétitif et une facilité d’utilisation, il a été décidé de créer en interne un logiciel répondant à ces critères en se basant sur les meilleurs composants open source. Ce nouveau logiciel devait offrir toutes les fonctionnalités d’une solution professionnelle d’Enterprise Search, apte à servir les besoins des applications internes. Ainsi naquit OpenSearchServer. Ce projet fut initié et mené par Emmanuel Keller, alors DSI de la filiale GISI Interactive, en charge d’une équipe de 20 ingénieurs dont 3 dédiés au projet. En 2008, une première application est créée, basé sur OpenSearchServer. Le succès de cette première application fut tel, qu’un an plus tard, OpenSearchServer était utilisé dans plus de dix applications. La qualité du logiciel, l’efficacité des applications s’appuyant dessus, ont forgé la conviction qu’un plus grand nombre d’entreprises pourrait être intéressé par son utilisation. A l’issue d’une réflexion avec la direction du groupe Infopro Communications, un accord fut trouvé. Emmanuel Keller quittait ses fonctions de DSI et acquérait l’intégralité des droits d’OpenSearchServer en décembre 2009. Infopro Communications devint logiquement le premier client de l’entreprise créée par Emmanuel en février 2010. Après une analyse approfondie du marché, l’élaboration d’un ambitieux plan de développement, la signature de premiers contrats, un groupe d’investisseurs menés par Kima Ventures fournit un premier tour de financement en février 2011. Depuis, la société a redoublé d’efforts pour développer l’équipe, attirer de nouveaux clients et écrire l’histoire de cette nouvelle compagnie. Adresse : Paris Incubateurs – Technologies Numeriques 15 rue Jean-Baptiste Berlier 75013 PARIS France contact@open-search-server.com View Larger Map Réseaux sociaux Tweets concernant "#opensearchserve OR opensearchserver OR "open search server" OR jaeksoft" Informations légales © 2013 OpenSearchServer Responsive Theme Propulsé par WordPress

Support Center SaaS Center Monitoring Center Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us About us Emmanuel Keller Chief Technical Officer Hugues Burghard Sales Manager Dr Serguei Victorov R&D Manager Naveen.A.N Development and QA Engineer OpenSearchServer began in 2007 in Infopro Communications , a French B2B media group with online and offline activities in news and information brokerage for 5 vertical segments. Because there wasn’t any existing Search solution which offered an appropriate mix of features, price and ease of use, it was decided to create some software internally which would use the most advanced Open source components available and provide unsurpassed functionality. The new software would offer all the necessary modules for professional Enterprise Search applications and would become a comprehensive solution that could be used in many different internal applications. The new software would be called OpenSearchServer. Right from the start, this project was led by Emmanuel Keller, CIO of the group, who had a team of 20 engineers, of whom 3 were dedicated to the project. In 2008, the first application was created with OpenSearchServer. Results were so positive that a year later, OpenSearchServer was in use in 10 more applications. The quality of the software, and the efficiency of the applications which were produced with it, convinced Emmanuel that a larger group of customers would be happy to use it. After some meetings with the CEO of the Infopro group, they reached an agreement. He resigned from his position and acquired all rights to OpenSearchServer in December 2009. Infopro Communications became his first customer and Emmanuel launched the new company in February 2010. After thorough analysis of the market, the design of an ambitious roadmap and the signing of the first contracts, a group of investors led by Kima Ventures provided the first round of financing in February 2011. Since then, the company has redoubled its efforts to grow the team, attract more customers and write the history of the young company. Address : Paris Incubateurs – Technologies Numeriques 15 rue Jean-Baptiste Berlier 75013 Paris France contact@open-search-server.com View Larger Map Social network Tweets concernant "#opensearchserve OR opensearchserver OR "open search server" OR jaeksoft" Legal information © 2013 OpenSearchServer Responsive Theme powered by WordPress

In 2008, the first application was created with OpenSearchServer. Results were so positive that a year later, OpenSearchServer was in use in 10 more applications. The quality of the software, and the efficiency of the applications which were produced with it, convinced Emmanuel that a larger group of customers would be happy to use it. After some meetings with the CEO of the Infopro group, they reached an agreement. He resigned from his position and acquired all rights to OpenSearchServer in December 2009. Infopro Communications became his first customer and Emmanuel launched the new company in February 2010. After thorough analysis of the market, the design of an ambitious roadmap and the signing of the first contracts, a group of investors led by Kima Ventures provided the first round of financing in February 2011. Since then, the company has redoubled its efforts to grow the team, attract more customers and write the history of the young company. Common API syntax Call syntax Variable Example Description server_name localhost The hostname of your OpenSearchServer instance port 8080 The TCP port of your server (on a SaaS instance it can be 80) application_path If you use the OpenSearchServer package, it may be /. If you are using a SaaS instance it can be some like /1679091c-5a88-3faf-afb5-e6087eb1b2dc index_name myindex The name of the index (it must be URL encoded). The monitor API don't need an index name. function_name update The name of the function. Usualy: update, search, delete, monitor... json|xml json The format which will be use for the reply and to upload data login myname If you have created a user in your OpenSearchServer instance this is the username (it must be URL encoded) api_key 5f27cb52b980a554e477131ebcb7a67f The API key to use for authentication (available in the Privileges tab panel of OpenSearchServer) Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English RESTful API: Update Tools Page History Info View in Hierarchy View Source RESTful API: Update Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Added by Emmanuel Keller , edited by Emmanuel Keller on Feb 18, 2013 Go to start of metadata You are viewing an old version of this page. View the current version . Compare with Current · View Page History << Previous Version 10 Current >> Description Use this API to insert documents in an index. Call syntax This API use the HTTP method POST. You can either post a document in XML format or in JSON format. Example of HTTP request Example of XML call Example of JSON call Request example using CURL Posting a document using CURL and XML Posting a document using CURL and JSON Document format The documents you want to insert in the index can either being describe in XML or JSON format. One request can contains several documents. Here is a minimalist example with a document containing two fields ( uri and title ). The language of the document is defined in the lang attribute. Inserting a document using XML It is possible to insert several values for one field. Both XML and JSON formats provide an easy way to do that. In this example, the field content will contains two values "Content1" and "Content2". The second value will be boosted by a factor 2. Inserting 2 documents using XML More example Inserting 2 documents using JSON Inserting one document using JSON API result JSON result XML result Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. This line was removed. Formatting was changed. ... We create first a query template which will search in the hostname field. To find it easily in the classifier , we call it "hostname". Now , we create a field which will contains the name of the category. Lets Let call it " category " . Then, we create a new classifier: For each website, we create one line. In the columns, please set we have to set the following values : Value : The name of the category. Boost : Keep it empty Query template : Select the "hostname" query. Query keywords : The hostname of the website. Check Finally, check the checkbox "enabled" and save the classifier. Now, each indexed document will be checked by passed to this classifier. If the hostname matches to one or more items of this classifier, the related value(s) will be copied in the "category" field. ... This line was removed. Formatting was changed. ... Parameters Description use It is the index name login (optional) The login parameter. This is required once you create a user. key (optional) The key parameter related to the login (api key). This is required once you create a user. action The action to perform: start, stop, and know status of the index. runOnce The runOnce parameter is to specify the crawler should run only once or forever. This is an boolean parameter. Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Evaluate Confluence today . Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home SaaS instructions Tools A ttachments (1) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source SaaS instructions Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Attachments: 1 Added by burghard , last edited by Emmanuel Keller on Sep 03, 2012 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata Find below the procedure to setup your OpenSearchServer instance on our Cloud infrastructure Choose the right offer on our Saas Services web page and click on the "subscription" button You are redirected to Paypal website. Please, follow Paypal instructions to setup the subscription. Once the subscription is valid, you will receive an email from OpenSearchServer with: Your access login and password. The permanent link to access the SaaS Center in order to manage your OpenSearchServer instance. The access link to Support Center to communicate with our technical support team. Connect to the SaaS Center to activate your OpenSearchServer instance. Click on "Configuration" button to choose your access login and passwordfor your newly OpenSearchServer instance. Click on "Start" button to start the instance. Congratulations! Your OpenSearchServer instance is now working. Click on "View" button to access to its web interface. Deploying new version of OpenSearchServer in SaaS instance - English - OpenSearchServer documentation

Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Need more help ? Take a look at our support services Starting at €79 for one month. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home SaaS instructions Deploying new version of OpenSearchServer in SaaS instance Tools A ttachments (0) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Deploying new version of OpenSearchServer in SaaS instance Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Oct 26, 2012 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata Find below the procedure to deploy new version of OpenSearchServer in you SaaS instance. Login to your SaaS Center . Click on the Stop button to stop the OpenSearchServer instance. Click on the undeploy button to undeploy the pervious version of OpenSearchServer. Click on the Start button to deploy the new version of OpenSearchServer automatically. You can login to your SaaS instance and check the latest version has been deployed. The information of the latest version can be found at the top left along with OpenSearchServer title. For example you can find something like this OpenSearchServer v1.3.1 - developer - rev 1904 - build 509. Inline help - Replication - English - OpenSearchServer documentation

Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Need more help ? Take a look at our support services Starting at €79 for one month. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home Inline Help Replication Inline help - Replication Tools A ttachments (1) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Inline help - Replication Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Attachments: 1 Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Nov 30, 2012 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata What is Replication ? Replication is a process of copying and distributing the index to one or more servers. Each replicated index can work indidually. There are four types of replication. Types Description Backup The replicated index can be used as backup. Main index The main index will be replicated. Web Crawler URL database The web crawler URL database will alone be replicated. File Crawler URI database The file crawler URI database will alone be replicated. How to create an replication for an index ? Before creating replication create an target index with Template Empty index. Replication type - The type of the replication. Instance URL - The target OpenSearchServer instance URL. By default this will be the current server URL. Index name - The name of the target index for replication. User name - User name login for authentication (or empty if no rights are required). API Key - API Key for authentication (or empty if no rights are required). Destination mode - There are two modes available . Read / write - In the read / write mode the index can be still writable. Read only - The index will be read only can't be updated. Click the Create button to create the replication item. A new replication item will be listed below. Running an replication The replication item has the details shown below. Instance URL - The target OpenSearchServer instance URL of the replication item. Replication type - The type of the replication item. Index Name - The name of the target index. Mode - The mode of the replication item. Last execution time - The time stamp of the replication item when it is last executed. Duration - The time taken to complete the replication process. Progression - The progress of the currently running process. Info - The information of the replication item such us the process is running ,completed or error. Action - The button is used to start the replication process. Click the button to start the replication. Once the replication is finished the info column gives the Completed message. Which informs that the source index has been replicated to target index. Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home Inline Help Replication Inline help - Replication Tools A ttachments (1) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Inline help - Replication Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Attachments: 1 Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Nov 30, 2012 ( view change ) Go to start of metadata What is Replication ? Replication is a process of copying and distributing the index to one or more servers. Each replicated index can work indidually. There are four types of replication. Types Description Backup The replicated index can be used as backup. Main index The main index will be replicated. Web Crawler URL database The web crawler URL database will alone be replicated. File Crawler URI database The file crawler URI database will alone be replicated. How to create an replication for an index ? Before creating replication create an target index with Template Empty index. Replication type - The type of the replication. Instance URL - The target OpenSearchServer instance URL. By default this will be the current server URL. Index name - The name of the target index for replication. User name - User name login for authentication (or empty if no rights are required). API Key - API Key for authentication (or empty if no rights are required). Destination mode - There are two modes available . Read / write - In the read / write mode the index can be still writable. Read only - The index will be read only can't be updated. Click the Create button to create the replication item. A new replication item will be listed below. Running an replication The replication item has the details shown below. Instance URL - The target OpenSearchServer instance URL of the replication item. Replication type - The type of the replication item. Index Name - The name of the target index. Mode - The mode of the replication item. Last execution time - The time stamp of the replication item when it is last executed. Duration - The time taken to complete the replication process. Progression - The progress of the currently running process. Info - The information of the replication item such us the process is running ,completed or error. Action - The button is used to start the replication process. Click the button to start the replication. Once the replication is finished the info column gives the Completed message. Which informs that the source index has been replicated to target index. Labels None Powered by a free Atlassian Confluence Open Source Project License granted to OpenSearchServer. Inline help - Runtime - OpenSearch - English - OpenSearchServer documentation

Home Features Pricing Documentation Community Newsletter Contact About us Need more help ? Take a look at our support services Starting at €79 for one month. Quick Search Browse Pages Blog Templates Labels Attachments Mail Advanced What’s New People Directory Space Directory Feed Builder Keyboard Shortcuts Confluence Gadgets Log In Sign Up Dashboard English Home Inline Help Runtime Inline help - Runtime - OpenSearch Tools A ttachments (1) Page History Restrictions Info Link to this Page… View in Hierarchy View Source Inline help - Runtime - OpenSearch Skip to end of metadata Page restrictions apply Attachments: 1 Added by Naveen , last edited by Naveen on Nov 30, 2012 Go to start of metadata What is OpenSearch Standard OpenSearch is a collection of simple formats for the sharing of search results. More details about OpenSearch Standard can be found here http://www.opensearch.org/Home Configuring OpenSearch User can configure the opensearch using the below settings. Select the query template A drop-down will gives the list of available query templates. Map the fields for OpenSearch User can map the index field with the opensearch fields. To map the field select the type of the field that is Field / Snippet . The index fields in the current field type will be listed. Click the button to add the field. Click the Save button to save settings. To view the opensearch standard click the view button.
